newsitem.title: BRAZIL: ING Barings sees Brazil exports up 8.0 pct in 97.
newsitem.headline: ING Barings sees Brazil exports up 8.0 pct in 97.

text.p: ING Barings said it expected Brazilian exports to increase about 8.0 percent in 1997.
ING Barings said in a statement that the foreign trade gap, which grew last year to $5.54 billion from $3.35 billion in 1995, should not widen significantly this year.
"Brazil's recently released foreign trade and current account deficit figures...are causing some concern among investors," the statement said.
The current account deficit in the 1996 balance of payments was equivalent to 3.27 percent of gross domestic product.

"However,...consumer and thus import demand is not likely to see rapid growth this year and with Brazil's exports expected to increase at around 8.0 percent in 1997, the foreign trade gap should not widen significantly," the statement added.
ING Barings said it expected export performance to improve due to recent measures taken by the government, including tax exemption, new and more productive investments and a bumper grains harvest.
It added "the chances are good" Brazil will not need to rein in domestic demand through restrictive credit and other policies.
The long-term challenge of increasing exports remained, however, ING Barings said.
